title: How did Portugal, given its proximity, never become conquered by Spain? - Quora

The answers here (up to the moment) where so good that I was obliged to upvote them all. Fair warning: I’m a Portuguese (check my bias). Apart from the excellent reasons (political and economic) already given, I just want to point out a few additional things. Pre-gunpowder Iberia 1) Portugal is mostly a very hilly, relatively barren terrain (not a very attractive country to conquer). 2) Portuguese military were very adept of “razia” (horseback guerrilla - there are really no good one-word translations), something that was learned from the moors and perfected to a “T”. Also we learned the art of the longbow (with early training) from the English and perfected the usage of the crossbow by isolated villagers - no invading column were “safe” in Portuguese lands. 3) Old people, women - even children - were indoctrinated into peaceful resistance (centuries before Mahatma Gandhi). Even today, it is a cultural feature that we don’t work for people we don’t like. Just as fish don’t notice there is such a thing as water, most Portuguese live their full lives unaware of a  cultural trait they carry. 4) Always at numerical disadvantage, Portuguese usage of terrain (and night) to their advantage became an art form. We could inundate vast plains, we could retreat to the mountains and stage ambushes over the entry passes into the country. In a pinch, Portuguese  soldiers could disguise themselves or “vanish” quite well into the landscape - as civilians or even trees - and carry on, practicing irregular and asymmetrical warfare (in small groups), and so on. 5) Having to maintain a permanent war against the Moors for centuries - a society that could dispose of 3/4 of its young males as munitions (the richer 1/4 could - and did - corral 4 females each) - prompted Iberian Christian societies (both Portugal and Spain - and Spaniards aren’t pushovers either) to change their demographics to survive: non first born (non inheriting) males, were mostly sent to the Monastic Orders - fierce fighters whose only chance of advancement was to distinguish themselves in battle. During the Age of Discoveries 1) Most wealth came from abroad. 2) Both Spain and Portugal were far more concerned with surveying the seven seas, closing rich trade deals and defending their overseas possessions than warring each other. Modern Era That didn’t stop Spain to send its proxies (from the Low Countries) to try to invade either Brazil or Angola. Here they were really at a numerical disadvantage and invariably were unsuccessful. Navy groups build on the other side of “the pond” (this nickname for the Atlantic Ocean was, secondly, Portuguese - “o nosso laguinho”, an echo of the Roman “Mare Nostrum”) always came to the rescue. When Napoleon decreed the Continental Blockade (and betrayed and invaded Spain) we didn’t obliged - opened our ports in South America and Africa to our allies - and took our lumps… Napoleon tried to invade Continental Portugal. Several times. England came to help with Wellington. Tens of thousands died defending - not a King that fled to Brazil - but our nation and our land. Indeed, but also to defend Brazil from French Invasion (Portugal and Brazil were the same country, then). For that, Brazilian gold was used to repay England (gold that, later on, ended up financing England's Industrialization, and ultimately defining the American matrix). Apparently, Brazilians are only told of half of this story (which make us cringe - for their lack of memory) that we took their gold away. But Portugal never was an English underling. Example: Portugal was one of the first powers of its day to recognize the independence - from England itself - of the 13 colonies on the eastern seaboard as the newly formed United States. It was the right thing to do at the time - and in our interests, of course (a stronger America would redefine us near the center of the world). Today Presently, the world has changed a lot. Spain and Portugal started as weak nations abandoned by the Roman Empire into disorder and chaos (and the middle ages) on the periphery of the [then] known world.. With the centuries of Oceanic Discoveries both Spain and Portugal “repositioned” themselves in the center of the Modern World. Nowadays we are so near that we see ourselves as brothers (and I speak for myself, every time I travel thru Spain) and we feel at home in each other countries (both the Portuguese and Spanish Languages are so close, we understand each other quite well). Also Spain and Portugal share basically the same [political and economic] interests. A “21st-century Iberian Union” would make sense indeed. Then again all of the (previously competing) Western Europe Countries (England, France, Italy, Portugal, Spain and so on) are like-minded friends, sharing similar interests, and belonging together in several “clubs” such as the EU, Schengen Area, NATO, etc. This might be new to others, but Spaniards and Portuguese take the long view and usually think in centuries, not years…

Ever thought of the opposite? Portugal conquering Spain? It happened on the 5th of June 1706, when a mostly Portuguese army led by the Marques das Minas, conquered Spain’s capital city, Madrid, and crowned Charles III King of Spain. This happened in the context of the war of Spanish Succession, in the early 18th century. ‘Spain’ is an incredibly modern construct - only after the War of Spanish Succession was Spain truly unified under one rule, one Monarch. Until then, there were several Iberian powers, which had emerged from the Reconquista, fighting for political control of the Peninsula - Portugal and Castille being the most prominent, but , for instance, Navarre and Aragon being also important players , sometimes assuring, sometimes disturbing the balance of power in the region. This struggle for Iberian supremacy lasted for many centuries, and involved many battles, many wars, and many royal weddings. It ended with the grand unification of most of the Iberian Peninsula under ‘Spain’, whilst the rest, which was controlled by the Portuguese Crown, became modern-day Portugal, and a tip (Gibraltar) which is, to this day, British. Most of the times, Iberian skirmishes involved the two most prominent powers, Portugal and Castille. The Portuguese defeated the Castillians in the Battle of Aljubarrota in 1385. Later, in the 15th century, as a consequence of the overall War of Castillian succession, in which the Portuguese king of the time got involved, the Battle of Toro was fought. Although the battle most likely ended in a stalemate, the Castillian-Aragonese allies reclaimed victory, leading to the marriage between Queen Isabella of Castille, and King Ferdinand of Aragon, famously known as the Catholic Kings. This event marked the foundation of modern day Spain. There were several peace treaties that followed, like for instance the Treaty of Alcáçovas, but this treaty was extremely unfavourable to the Castillians, and was several times renegotiated. Later, in 1498, the two crowns divided the World in the Treaty of Tordesilhas, the consequences of which are still visible in a world map to this day. With the early death of King Sebastian I of Portugal in the Battle of Alcazar, in 1578, a Succession crisis ensued, leading to the coronation of King Phillip II of Spain, as King Phillip I of Portugal in 1580. Whether it can be said that Spain invaded Portugal is contested to this day, since Phillip I was the son of Charles V and Isabella of Portugal, and therefore, King Sebastian’s uncle, and thus had, very likely, the most legitimate claim to the throne of Portugal. In fact, Phillip I was formally recognised as King of Portugal in the cortes de Tomar of 1581. Also, it should be noted that the new King's election was carried on condition that the kingdom and its overseas territories should remain separate from Spain and keep their own laws and Cortes. This led to the Iberian Union, in which Spain and Portugal would remain united in a personal union of the crowns (remaining formally independent and with autonomous administrations) for the next 60 years. In 1640 after a swift revolution that happened in Lisbon, John, duke of Braganza was acclamed as John IV, King of Portugal, establishing the powerful House of Braganza as the new ruling dinasty of Portugal. The war between the two countries lasted from 1640 until 1668. The two decisive battles of Castelo Rodrigo and Montes Claros, ended with Portuguese victories. These definitely secured Portuguese independence, and led to the Treaty of Lisbon in 1668, in which Spain formally recognised the House of Braganza as the ruling House of Portugal. After an initial period of peace, Portugal saw itself involved in the War of Spanish Succession, and although King Pedro II initially sided with the Bourbon faction, it later changed sides to better reflect Portuguese interests (mostly, Atlantic trade), and joined the war. It was during this period that the Marques das Minas conquered Madrid in 1706, as mentioned before. In the 19th century, as Portugal refused to join Napoleon’s Continental Blockade against the British, Napoleon had Spain invaded, and placed his cousin on the Throne, whilst attempting to invade Portugal several times. An Anglo-Portuguese army later defeated Napoleon’s army and liberated both Spain and Portugal from French rule. After that there were little to no attempts at either country wanting to go to war with the other. Today both countries enjoy an excellent relationship, and are partners not only within the framework of the European Union, but also through countless bilateral agreements. So to make a long story short, the question is perhaps oversimplified. One should take into account the historical context in which both countries were created, and developed, and how events played out throughout the many centuries of their existence, in order to understand the intricate, sometimes friendly, sometimes even hostile relations between Portugal and the rest of Spain.

Please note that I'm basing this in my previous answer to a similar question: Why weren't Spain and Portugal united in a similar way to Aragon and Castille?  First, why should it have been conquered by Spain? - The same could be applied to all neighbouring countries in the world, "How did xxxx, given its proximity, never become conquered by yyy?".  OK. Being honest I could also answer that it was tried at some moments... but never successfully. Let's have a quick overview: Spain and Portugal took separate paths in history a loooong time ago: In 1139 Afonso Henriques seceded his then "County" from the Kingdom of León, becoming the first King of Portugal (Afonso I). That "independence" was recognized in 1143 by the Pope (Papal recognition was considered very relevant in those times!!) and by the King of León (Treaty of Zamora).During some periods the neighbouring Kingdom of Castile wasn't too happy with Portugal's independence, and on several occasions attempted to "control it", often trying to take advantage of, or in relation with, dynastic or succession problems (that were common in those times). But with no success. A significant event during this period is the Portuguese victory over Castille at Aljubarrota (1385)After 1580, and again as a consequence of dynastic problems, Portugal and Spain were ruled by the same Kings... of Spain (Philip II + two others). This period is known as the "Iberian Union". But even then they still were different kingdoms (... yes, with a common King).... But this "Union" was unsatisfactory to most Portuguese people, and unilaterally put to an end in 1640 when the Duke of Braganza was acclaimed as King João IV of Portugal by Portuguese nobility.That started a war with Spain (Known in Portugal as the Guerra da Restauração, Portuguese Restoration War), that ended in 1668 when the King of Spain signed the "Treaty of Lisbon", fully recognising Portugal's independence. Please note that this conflict must be understood in the wider context of the pan-european Thirty-years war, and had complex international implications: Portugal has always been a British ally, Spain was at that moment an ally of France.After that there were more wars between the two countries in the 18th century, some of them even based mostly in South America (Spanish–Portuguese War (1735–37)). One of them, in 1762-1763, is often known as the "Fantastic War" - as there were no battles: it was also part of an pan-European conflict, in this case of the Seven Years' WarIn short: Spain has tried - and never succeeded (... hard guys, these neighbours!!). AND many of the more recent wars between the two countries have just been part of different alignments in pan-european conflicts.... where, apparently, none of the two countries was really interested in directly fighting with the other :-). Both Spain and Portugal have a rich, complex and interesting history - and share rich, complex and interesting parts of it. Oh, and many of us wouldn't mind to have some sort of "21st-century Iberian Union". As I see it, a closer relation between Spain and Portugal would be good for both. It is an admirable country, and they are great people :).

Hello! Well, first of all,Portugal is as notorious (or even more) as Spain for its conquests across the globe. In the 15th and 16th centuries, Portugal and Spain discovered A great part of Africa, Asia, and America. By the Tordesillas Treaty(1494), the two centuries divided among them the already discovered lands and decided that on the left of an imaginary land, next dicoveries would be Portuguese and on the right of that line they would be for Spain. Secondly, Spain, as we know it is a much more recent country than Portugal. When we say “Spain” we think of several countries that were called Castilla, Léon, Aragón, and so on. On the contrary, Portugal is a unified country with the most ancient European borders. Our continental borders were fixed since 1297. So, the two countries have subsisted as independents since they were formed, with the exception of the period between 1580 and 1640, when the Spanish kings were also recognizesd as Portuguese kings. That became possible because the Portuguese king Sebastião died in battle, without having sons. The next in the family tree was the King Philip the second of Spain, through his wife. Therefore, he became Philip the first of Portugal. But even during that period, there was not a fusion between the two countries. Portugal was always considered as an autonomous country, with its own laws and way of life. There were 3 Spanish kings ruling over Portugal but the third one began to disrespect the autonomy of Portugal and to appoint for high government charges incompetent people. Portugal also suffered with the wars that Spain led against its own ennemies. So, in 1640, people made a revolution and raise to the throne the head of Bragança House, who became king John the fourth and broke free of Spaniish rule. Portuguese and Spanish people love each other, they share a splendid relationship, but they are different in several aspects and both are proud and fierce about their independence.

I have given this answer to a similar question: In just a few words because of the Portuguese maritime expansion! Portugal started as part of the spanish kingdom of Leon and became self ruled in the XII century (1143 by the treaty of Zamora between Afonso Henriques, the first portuguese King and Afonso VII Emperor Hispaneae, who recognized portuguese independence but held the portuguese monarch as a vassal or 1179 when the Pope Alexander III formally recognized Portugal and took it as a vassal). It could have just been one of those fleeting spanish kingdoms that existed between the X and the XVI century, in fact in 1383, when king Fernando I died, we almost became united to Castilla, as the King married his only daughter to King John I of Castilla and their heir was supposed to have united the two crowns. However the queen mother who stood as regent was quite unpopular and the Bastard son of a previous king, Master of the Order of Avis staged a coup with the backing of the arraia miuda (the people, in particular the merchants of the big towns, Lisbon and Porto) and the Castillians were defeated in several battles, putting an end to the attempted union. The next opportunity was at the death of Henry the IV of Castilla, when the Portuguese king Afonso V claimed the throne, but Isabel married her cousin Fernando of Aragon and together they defeated the portuguese at the battle of Toro, ending a chance of an union headed by Portugal. Afonso V was the last portuguese feudal monarch. In 1480 the Prince Perfect John II became King of Portugal and not only accelerated portuguese maritime expansion, with the goal of reaching India, but he created the modern state by subduing part of the aristocracy (phisically eliminating some of the most high ranking noblemen) and centralizing power with the revenue of the gold from the coast of Guinea (Mina), making Portugal the first modern European nation state. Based on his vision and that of his successor Manuel I, Portugal became a global power and the deeds were celebrated in an epic poem by the poet Camões, who both helped establish the portuguese language and created an idea of Portugal that the portuguese would rally around during the dark times of spanish rule (while others have noted that the kingdom of Portugal remained separated, Portugal was forced into disastrous wars with many of Spain’s enemies, in who were our main customers and traditional allies and since portuguese colonies were not a priority many territories were lost essentially to the Dutch, and while many portuguese gladly supported the union, in particular the nobility, Portugal was under occupation, a spanish garrison was kept in Lisbon a spanish governor resided in Lisbon and political prisoners filled the jails). In the reign of Filipe IV (Filipe III in Portugal) attempts were made to centralize power, a moved that if accomplished would have resulted in the complete loss of a separate identity, and that the Portuguese, who by then had a fully separated identity, raised in the epic deeds of their predecessors and having the self esteem of having build a large empire, defeating great powers all over the world could not stomach, so they killed the main arm of the spanish rule, the secretary of state and imprisoned the spanish governoress and proclaimed independence. Curiously, the time of the Catholic Monarchs, who faced off with the Portuguese at least twice (the War of Castilian Succession, and the events that led to the Treaty of Tordesillas) was the moment in which the unification of the entire Peninsula under one crown became not only most likely, but perhaps even desired. The War of Castilian Succession saw Castile divided in two, with one side supporting Isabel de Trastámara, daughter of King Enrique IV, and the other supporting Enrique's supposed daughter Juana "La Beltraneja" (so called because it was suspected her biological dad was actually Beltrán de la Cueva, the King's favourite). Aragón joined Isabel's side, and Portugal and France joined Juana's side. Isabel won, and the Treaty of Alcaçovas was signed between Castile and Portugal. One of the terms of said treaty was that Isabel, the eldest daughter of Fernando and Isabel, was to marry Prince John's (future John II of Portugal) son and heir, Afonso. Years later, Isabel and Afonso got married and actually fell in love almost instantly. Meanwhile, the Catholic Monarchs' heir, Juan, was an ill child that was many times at the edge of death, and Isabel and Fernando were worried that, if Juan died, their throne would end up in the hands of Afonso and Isabel, which would probably mean greater influence of Portugal in Castile, something they had fought for so long to avoid. Afonso died in strange circumstances, with some blaming the Monarchs for arranging the then heir's death. The second possibility was when Isabel got married to John II's cousin, Manuel I of Portugal (despite her wishes to become a nun after her first husband's death). She got pregnant and died giving birth to a child that was called Miguel da Paz. Miguel fell under the care of his maternal grandparents, Isabel and Fernando, and plans were made to groom him to become the future King of Aragon, Castile and Portugal, with a greater influence from the Castilian side. Unfortunately, Miguel died at age 2. The next chance was with the Habsburg kings, from Philip II to Philip IV. The former had inherited the crown through his mother, Isabel of Portugal, after the last of the Avis monarchs, Henrique, died without issue (he was a cardinal, and was not allowed to drop his vows to have a heir), and Philip II had the biggest claim to the crown. Of course, the Habsburg squanderd the chance to fully unite the Iberian Peninsula (see, they were quite jerkasses towards the Portuguese) and they separated again in 1640. Finally, the last chance is one that barely had a chance (heh) of happening. When Isabel II of Spain was forced to abdicate in 1868, there were several candidates to the crown. One of them was the former King Consort of Portugal, Fernando II, who renounced to the crown because he did not want to be again part of the political life. And another was Leopold zu Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen, who was married to the Infanta Antónia, sister of the then King of Portugal, Luis I. With the proper series of coincidences (pretty much meaning that Luís I and his descendants had to die), Leopold could have found himself King of Spain and King Consort of Portugal, leading to a potential unification of the two countries. For more information, please, do not doubt to read The Legacy of the Glorious (Milarqui's Cut).

The answer to this question lies in a series of inter-dynastic marriages between the Houses of Aviz (of Burgundian/Alfonsine Portugese royalty) and Trastamara (royalty of Castille/Aragon/Leon) and a rather singular conflict which changed the course of Iberian colonialism and inter-nation relations for years to come. It was a very important time for the Iberian Peninsula, when the the collection of individual Kingdoms we know as "Spain" was coming together, and the last War of the  Reconquista (or the driving out of the moors was about to happen) under the Catholic Monarchs. The Spanish and Portuguese royalty extensively intermarried. as such there were always competing claims from either household for the several crowns of Kingdoms in Portugal or Castille or Aragon or Galicia or Leon and so forth. The same was the case with the War of the Castilian Succession which precedes the War of the Portuguese Succession User-10333582167263462789 mentions. Please refer wiki for the relations among the claimants to the throne of Castille and how the battle played out. However, the War of the Castillian Succession is important to us because it gave rise to the Treaty of Alcáçovas, a gamechanger in the power-politics of Europe. The War was fought both on land and sea, resulting in a Castillian victory on land and a Portuguese victory at sea.  The Treaty for the first time ever, delineated the spheres of influence of colonial powers clearly, and Portugal scored a major victory here in terms of negotiation. It retained a virtual hegemony over all territories discovered and to be discovered between Canary Islands (which alone Castille could retain) and Guinea (which Portugal retained). This was also a landmark treaty for it marks the first time European powers "shared" colonies amongst themselves, a model which would be followed for several centuries to come. Arguably although this set the stage for Treaty of Tordesillas, but nevertheless aided by the "insurance" of inter-dynastic marriage, Papal Bulls confirming "colonial sharing" treaties, strategic alliances etc., each was left more or less alone especially post Iberian Union times (which User-10333582167263462789 mentions) to build Empires. And the Empires became reinforcing deterrent engines of cementing their strategic independence, as there were several theatres of war, greater money involved, higher losses etc. Hope this helps!

Indeed Spain found it hard to retain these territories (the Austrian Habsburgs and Italian princes wanted them too). As of the end of the Napoleonic wars, Spain had become quite weak and Portugal could have been quite hard to control because the Portuguese had a strong national identity. As of the end of the Napoleonic wars, simple annexions in the old way had become harder and harder to keep because the people simply did not accept being robbed of their national rulers. Also, the UK wanted Portugal to remain independent.

response.answer_text: There are some great answers in this thread, so little else to add but this: The dream of unification, worked hard by the Catholic Kings, Isabel and Fernando, and the wars waged by the Emperor Carlos I to solidify the Spanish Power in Europe were absolutely successful. By the time of King Felipe II, his Empire was the largest the world had ever seen. All of Iberia, Belgium and Netherlands, parts of Italy and all the lands discovered and conquered by both Spaniard and Lusitan conquistadores. They were one Empire, one in which the Sun never set. And now Phillip II had a decision to make: Where to set up the new capital of Spain, and by extension of the world? Old Toledo was too small, too medieval for the 'superpower' of the time (neither France, nor England, nor Austria or the Ottomans were a match for the Spanish Tercios in those years), so a new seat of power was needed, and that's how Madrid was selected, looking inwards to Europe and the old Spanish center... and the rest is history.  A better selection that would have changed the fates of Spain and Portugal, and the world, forever? Ancient and Regal Lisboa, where the King could look to the Seas and to the New World, where riches and opportunities and power laid. *sigh*

First, what you call Spain is named this way since Modern Age. So everyone in Portugal was Portuguese and Spanish. The same applied to Castilians. Only after 1640 Portugal considered itself as non-Spanish as a sign of "we are not ruled by the king in Madrid". In fact, only with the Bourbons, the kings in Spain, called themselves "Kings of Spain". Usually they called themselves "King of Leon, Castile, Aragon,  Navarra....." During the late Middle Ages, Castile had two options:  Go west and conquer Portugal, which was a Christian Kingdom (that was really important in those days), had allies, and could imply having problems with the Pope, or,Go south and conquer Muslim kingdoms with the Pope's blessing.As far as I know, the only times Castile tried to conquer Portugal was in 1385 and 1580. Both times Castilian king alleged having a claim over the Portuguese throne, which is the way a Christian king could fight another one. In 1580, King Philip II succeeded.

The main reason is because Portugal, throughout most of its history as an independent nation, had a very powerful ally that went by the names "England," "Great Britain," and the "United Kingdom" at various points in its history, and this ally was extremely hostile to Spain during the era in which Spain would have attempted the conquest of Portugal, or when it attempted to regain control of Portugal after the Portuguese ended their personal union with the Spanish Habsburgs in 1640. For the same reason, Portugal never became a Napoleonic satrapy during the First French Empire, because the British helped defend it after Napoleon had foisted his brother on the Spanish throne. Except for the period between 1580 and 1640 when the Crowns of Spain and Portugal were united, the alliance between England/Britain/UK and Portugal has been in continuous force since 1386. (English assistance to Portugal actually dates back to the Second Crusade in 1147, but there was no formal alliance at that time.) After Portugal freed itself from the Habsburgs, it immediately reconfirmed the 1386 treaty.

During the Reconquista Spain wasn’t a nation. It was a geographic expression. Christian Iberia was split between the kingdoms of Navarre, Castile, Leon and Aragon, plus the Counties of Barcelona and Portugal. Gradually, these states were gathered into one kingdom by the Trastamura dynasty, forming the Kingdom of Spain under Ferdinand and Isabella in 1469. Their great-grandson, Philip II, also inherited Portugal in 1580, unifying the peninsula for the first (and last) time. But Philip’s grandson Philip IV lost Portugal to a rebellion in 1640, restoring the division that continues to this day.
